Abstract

This paper gives a dichotomy theorem for the complexity of computing the partition function of an instance of a weighted Boolean constraint satisfaction problem. The problem is parameterised by a finite setÂ â„±â„±\mathcal{F} of non-negative functions that may be used to assign weights to the configurations (feasible solutions) of a problem instance. Classical constraint satisfaction problems correspond to the special case of 0,1-valued functions. We show that computing the partition function, i.e. the sum of the weights of all configurations, is FP#PsuperscriptFP#P\mbox{\sf FP}^{\mbox{\scriptsize\sf\#P}}-complete unless either (1)Â every function inÂ â„±â„±\mathcal{F} is of â€œproduct typeâ€, or (2) every function inÂ â„±â„±\mathcal{F} is â€œpure affineâ€. In the remaining cases, computing the partition function is in P.

1 Introduction

This paper gives a dichotomy theorem for the complexity of the partition function of weighted Boolean constraint satisfaction problems. Such problems are parameterised by a setÂ â„±â„±\mathcal{F} of non-negative functions that may be used to assign weights to configurations (solutions) of the instance. These functions take the place of the allowed constraint relations in classical constraint satisfaction problems (CSPs). Indeed, the classical setting may be recovered by restricting â„±â„±\mathcal{F} to functions with range {0,1}01\{0,1\}. The key problem associated with an instance of a weighted CSP is to compute its partition function, i.e., the sum of weights of all its configurations. Computing the partition function of a weighted CSP may be viewed a generalisation of counting the number of satisfying solutions of a classical CSP. Many partition functions from statistical physics may be expressed as weighted CSPs. For example, the Potts modelÂ [23] is naturally expressible as a weighted CSP, whereas in the classical framework only the â€œhard coreâ€ versions may be directly expressed. (The hard-core version of the antiferromagnetic Potts model corresponds to graph colouring and the hard-core version of the ferromagnetic Potts model is trivial â€” acceptable configurations colour the entire graph with a single colour.) A corresponding weighted version of the decision CSP was investigated by Cohen, Cooper, Jeavons and KrokhinÂ [3]. This results in optimisation problems.

We use #CSPâ€‹(â„±)#CSPâ„±\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) to denote the problem of computing the partition function of weighted CSP instances that can be expressed using only functions fromÂ â„±â„±\mathcal{F}. We show in TheoremÂ 4 below that if every function fâˆˆâ„±ğ‘“â„±f\in\mathcal{F} is â€œof product typeâ€ then computing the partition function Zâ€‹(I)ğ‘ğ¼Z(I) of an instanceÂ Iğ¼I can be done in polynomial time. Formal definitions are given later, but the condition of being â€œof product typeâ€ is easily checked â€” it essentially means that the partition function factors. We show further in TheoremÂ 4 that if every function fâˆˆâ„±ğ‘“â„±f\in\mathcal{F} is â€œpure affineâ€ then the partition function of Zâ€‹(I)ğ‘ğ¼Z(I) can be computed in polynomial time. Once again, there is an algorithm to check whether â„±â„±\mathcal{F} is pure affine. For each other setÂ â„±â„±\mathcal{F}, we show in TheoremÂ 4 that computing the partition function of a #CSPâ€‹(â„±)#CSPâ„±\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) instance is complete for the class FP#PsuperscriptFP#P\mbox{\sf FP}^{\mbox{\scriptsize\sf\#P}}. The existence of algorithms for testing the properties of being purely affine or of product type means that the dichotomy is effectively decidable.

1.1 Constraint satisfaction

Constraint Satisfaction, which originated in Artificial Intelligence, provides a general framework for modelling decision problems, and has many practical applications. (See, for exampleÂ [18].) Decisions are modelled by variables, which are subject to constraints, modelling logical and resource restrictions. The paradigm is sufficiently broad that many interesting problems can be modelled, from satisfiability problems to scheduling problems and graph-theory problems. Understanding the complexity of constraint satisfaction problems has become a major and active area within computational complexityÂ [7, 14].

A Constraint Satisfaction Problem (CSP) typically has a finite domain, which we will denote by [q]={0,1â€‹â€¦,qâˆ’1}delimited-[]ğ‘01â€¦ğ‘1[q]=\left\{0,1\ldots,q-1\right\} for a positive integerÂ qğ‘q.111 Usually [q]delimited-[]ğ‘[q] is defined to be {1,2,â€¦,q}12â€¦ğ‘\left\{1,2,\ldots,q\right\}, but it is more convenient here to start the enumeration of domain elements atÂ 0 rather thanÂ 1. A constraint language Î“Î“\Gamma with domain [q]delimited-[]ğ‘[q] is a set of relations onÂ [q]delimited-[]ğ‘[q]. For example, take q=2ğ‘2q=2. The relation R={(0,0,1)R=\{(0,0,1), (0,1,0)010(0,1,0), (1,0,0)100(1,0,0), (1,1,1)}(1,1,1)\} is a 3-ary relation on the domain {0,1}01\{0,1\}, with four tuples.

Once we have fixed a constraint language Î“Î“\Gamma, an instance of the CSP is a set of variables V={v1,â€¦,vn}ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›V=\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\} and a set of constraints. Each constraint has a scope, which is a tuple of variables (for example, (v4,v5,v1)subscriptğ‘£4subscriptğ‘£5subscriptğ‘£1(v_{4},v_{5},v_{1})) and a relation fromÂ Î“Î“\Gamma of the same arity, which constrains the variables in the scope. A configuration Ïƒğœ\sigma is a function fromÂ Vğ‘‰V toÂ [q]delimited-[]ğ‘[q]. The configurationÂ Ïƒğœ\sigma is satisfying if the scope of every constraint is mapped to a tuple that is in the corresponding relation. In our example above, a configuration Ïƒğœ\sigma satisfies the constraint with scope (v4,v5,v1)subscriptğ‘£4subscriptğ‘£5subscriptğ‘£1(v_{4},v_{5},v_{1}) and relationÂ Rğ‘…R if and only if it maps an odd number of the variables in {v1,v4,v5}subscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘£4subscriptğ‘£5\{v_{1},v_{4},v_{5}\} to the valueÂ 111. Given an instance of a CSP with constraint language Î“Î“\Gamma, the decision problem CSP(Î“\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) asks us to determine whether any configuration is satisfying. The counting problem #CSP(Î“\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) asks us to determine the number of (distinct) satisfying configurations.

Varying the constraint languageÂ Î“Î“\Gamma defines the classes CSP and #CSP of decision and counting problems. These contain problems of different computational complexities. For example, if Î“={R1,R2,R3}Î“subscriptğ‘…1subscriptğ‘…2subscriptğ‘…3\Gamma=\{R_{1},R_{2},R_{3}\} where R1subscriptğ‘…1R_{1}, R2subscriptğ‘…2R_{2} and R3subscriptğ‘…3R_{3} are the three binary relations defined by R1={(0,1),(1,0),(1,1)}subscriptğ‘…1011011R_{1}=\{(0,1),(1,0),(1,1)\}, R2={(0,0),(0,1),(1,1)}subscriptğ‘…2000111R_{2}=\{(0,0),(0,1),(1,1)\} and R3={(0,0),(0,1),(1,0)}subscriptğ‘…3000110R_{3}=\{(0,0),(0,1),(1,0)\}, then CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is the classical 2-Satisfiability problem, which is in P. On the other hand, there is a similar constraint languageÂ Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} with four relations of arityÂ 3 such that 3-Satisfiability (which is NP-complete) can be represented in CSPâ€‹(Î“â€²)CSPsuperscriptÎ“â€²\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma^{\prime}). It may happen that the counting problem is harder than the decision problem. If Î“Î“\Gamma is the constraint language of 2-Satisfiability above, then #CSPâ€‹(Î“)#CSPÎ“\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) contains the problem of counting independent sets in graph, and is #P-completeÂ [22], even if restricted to 3-regular graphsÂ [12].

Any decision problem CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is in NP, but not every problem in NP can be represented as a CSP. For example, the question â€œIs GğºG Hamiltonian?â€ cannot naturally be expressed as a CSP, because the property of being Hamiltonian cannot be captured by relations of bounded size. This limitation of the class CSP has an important advantage. If Pâ‰ NPPNP\mbox{\sf P}\neq\mbox{\sf NP}, then there are problems which are neither in P nor NP-completeÂ [16]. But, for well-behaved smaller classes of decision problems, the situation can be simpler. We may have a dichotomy theorem, partitioning all problems in the class into those which are in P and those which are NP-complete. There are no â€œleftoverâ€ problems of intermediate complexity. It has been conjectured that there is a dichotomy theorem for CSP. The conjecture is that CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is in P for some constraint languages Î“Î“\Gamma, and CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is NP-complete for all other constraint languages Î“Î“\Gamma. This conjecture appeared in a seminal paper of Feder and VardiÂ [10], but has not yet been proved.

A similar dichotomy, between FP and #P-complete, is conjectured for #CSPÂ [2]. The complexity classes FP and #P are the analogues of P and NP for counting problems. FP is simply the class of functions computable in deterministic polynomial time. #P is the class of integer functions that can be expressed as the number of accepting computations of a polynomial-time non-deterministic Turing machine. Completeness in #P is defined with respect to polynomial-time Turing reducibilityÂ [17, Chap.Â 18]. Bulatov and DalmauÂ [2] have shown in one direction that, if #CSPâ€‹(Î“)#CSPÎ“\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) is solvable in polynomial time, then the constraints in Î“Î“\Gamma must have certain algebraic properties (assuming Pâ‰ #PP#P\mbox{\sf P}\neq\mbox{\sf\#P}). In particular, they must have a so-called Malâ€™tsev polymorphism. The converse is known to be false, though it remains possible that the dichotomy (if it exists) does have an algebraic characterisation.

The conjectured dichotomies for CSP and #CSP are major open problems for computational complexity theory. There have been many important results for subclasses of CSP and #CSP. We mention the most relevant to our paper here. The first decision dichotomy was that of SchaeferÂ [19], for the Boolean domain {0,1}01\{0,1\}. Schaeferâ€™s result is as follows.

Theorem 1 (SchaeferÂ [19]).

Let Î“Î“\Gamma be a constraint language with domain {0,1}01\{0,1\}. The problem CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is in P if Î“Î“\Gamma satisfies one of the conditions below. Otherwise, CSPâ€‹(Î“)CSPÎ“\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is NP-complete.

  1. (1)

    Î“Î“\Gamma is 00-valid or 111-valid.

  2. (2)

    Î“Î“\Gamma is weakly positive or weakly negative.

  3. (3)

    Î“Î“\Gamma is affine.

  4. (4)

    Î“Î“\Gamma is bijunctive.

We will not give detailed definitions of the conditions in TheoremÂ 1, but the interested reader is referred to the paperÂ [19] or to TheoremÂ 6.2 of the textbookÂ [7]. An interesting feature is that the conditions inÂ [7, TheoremÂ 6.2] are all checkable. That is, there is an algorithm to determine whether CSP(Î“\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is in P or NP-complete, given a constraint languageÂ Î“Î“\Gamma with domainÂ {0,1}01\{0,1\}. Creignou and HermannÂ [6] adapted Schaeferâ€™s decision dichotomy to obtain a counting dichotomy for the Boolean domain. Their result is as follows.

Theorem 2 (Creignou and HermannÂ [6]).

Let Î“Î“\Gamma be a constraint language with domain {0,1}01\{0,1\}. The problem #CSPâ€‹(Î“)#CSPÎ“\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) is in FP if Î“Î“\Gamma is affine. Otherwise, #CSPâ€‹(Î“)#CSPÎ“\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) is #P-complete.

A constraint languageÂ Î“Î“\Gamma with domain {0,1}01\{0,1\} is affine if every relation RâˆˆÎ“ğ‘…Î“R\in\Gamma is affine. A relation Rğ‘…R is affine if the set of tuplesÂ xâˆˆRğ‘¥ğ‘…x\in R is the set of solutions to a system of linear equations over GF(222). These equations are of the form v1âŠ•â‹¯âŠ•vn=0direct-sumsubscriptğ‘£1â‹¯subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›0v_{1}\oplus\cdots\oplus v_{n}=0 and v1âŠ•â‹¯âŠ•vn=1direct-sumsubscriptğ‘£1â‹¯subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›1v_{1}\oplus\cdots\oplus v_{n}=1 where âŠ•direct-sum\oplus is the exclusive or operator. It is well known (see, for example, LemmaÂ 4.10 ofÂ [7]) that a relation Rğ‘…R is affine iff a,b,câˆˆRğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘…a,b,c\in R implies d=aâŠ•bâŠ•câˆˆRğ‘‘direct-sumğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘…d=a\oplus b\oplus c\in R. (We will use this characterisation below.) There is an algorithm for determining whether a Boolean constraint language Î“Î“\Gamma is affine, so there is an algorithm for determining whether #CSPâ€‹(Î“)#CSPÎ“\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) is in FP or #P-complete.

1.3 Some Notation

We will call the class of (rational) weighted #CSP problems weighted #CSP. The sub-class having domain size q=2ğ‘2q=2 will be called weighted Boolean #CSP, and will be the main focus of this paper. We will give a dichotomy theorem for weighted Boolean #CSP.

Since weights can be arbitrary non-negative rational numbers, the solution to these problems is not an integer in general. Therefore #CSPâ€‹(â„±)#CSPâ„±\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) is not necessarily in the classÂ #P. However, Goldberg and JerrumÂ [11] have observed that Zâ€‹(I)=Z~â€‹(I)/Kâ€‹(I)ğ‘ğ¼~ğ‘ğ¼ğ¾ğ¼Z(I)=\tilde{Z}(I)/K(I), where Z~~ğ‘\tilde{Z} is a function in #P and Kâ€‹(I)ğ¾ğ¼K(I) is a positive integer computable in FP. This follows because, for all fâˆˆâ„±ğ‘“â„±f\in\mathcal{F}, we can ensure that fâ€‹(â‹…)=f~â€‹(â‹…)/Kâ€‹(I)ğ‘“â‹…~ğ‘“â‹…ğ¾ğ¼f(\cdot)=\tilde{f}(\cdot)/K(I), where f~â€‹(â‹…)âˆˆâ„•~ğ‘“â‹…â„•\tilde{f}(\cdot)\in\mathbb{N}, byâ€œclearing denominatorsâ€. The denominator Kâ€‹(I)ğ¾ğ¼K(I) can obviously be computed in polynomial time, and it is straightforward to show that computing Z~â€‹(I)~ğ‘ğ¼\tilde{Z}(I) is in #P, so the characterisation ofÂ [11] follows. The resulting complexity class, comprising functions which are a function in #P divided by a function in FP, is named #Pâ„šsubscript#Pâ„š\mbox{\sf\#P}_{\mathbb{Q}} inÂ [11], where it is used in the context of approximate counting. Clearly we have

weightedâ€‹#CSPâŠ†#Pâ„šâŠ†FP#P.weighted#CSPsubscript#Pâ„šsuperscriptFP#P\textsf{weighted}\,\mbox{\sf\#CSP}\ \subseteq\ \mbox{$\mbox{\sf\#P}_{\mathbb{Q}}$}\ \subseteq\ \mbox{\sf FP}^{\mbox{\scriptsize\sf\#P}}.

On the other hand, if Zâ€‹(I)âˆˆweightedâ€‹#CSPğ‘ğ¼weighted#CSPZ(I)\in\textsf{weighted}\,\mbox{\sf\#CSP} is #P-hard, then, using an oracle for computing Z(IZ(I), we can construct a #P oracle Z~â€‹(I)~ğ‘ğ¼\tilde{Z}(I) as outlined above. (Note that Zâ€‹(I)âˆ‰#Pğ‘ğ¼#PZ(I)\notin\mbox{\sf\#P} in general.) We will use this observation to state our main result in terms of completeness for the class FP#PsuperscriptFP#P\mbox{\sf FP}^{\mbox{\scriptsize\sf\#P}}.

We make the following definition, which relates to the discussion above. 1.4 Our Result

Our main result is the following.

Theorem 4.

Suppose â„±âŠ†â„±2={f:{0,1}kâ†’â„š+âˆ£kâˆˆâ„•}â„±subscriptâ„±2conditional-setğ‘“â†’superscript01ğ‘˜conditionalsuperscriptâ„šğ‘˜â„•\mathcal{F}\subseteq\mathcal{F}_{2}=\{f:\left\{0,1\right\}^{k}\to\mathbb{Q}^{+}\mid k\in\mathbb{N}\}. Otherwise, #CSPâ€‹(â„±)#CSPâ„±\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) is FP#PsuperscriptFP#P\mbox{\sf FP}^{\mbox{\scriptsize\sf\#P}}-complete.

Proof.

Suppose first that â„±â„±\mathcal{F} is of product type. In this case the partition function Zâ€‹(I)ğ‘ğ¼Z(I) of an instanceÂ Iğ¼I with variable setÂ Vğ‘‰V is easy to evaluate because it can be factored into easy-to-evaluate pieces: Partition the variables inÂ Vğ‘‰V into equivalence classes according to whether or not they are related by an equality or disequality function. (The equivalence relation on variables here is â€œdepends linearly onâ€.) An equivalence class consists of two (possibly empty) sets of variables U1subscriptğ‘ˆ1U_{1} and U2subscriptğ‘ˆ2U_{2}. All of the variables inÂ U1subscriptğ‘ˆ1U_{1} must be assigned the same value by a configurationÂ Ïƒğœ\sigma of nonzero weight, and all variables inÂ U2subscriptğ‘ˆ2U_{2} must be assigned the other value. Variables in U1âˆªU2subscriptğ‘ˆ1subscriptğ‘ˆ2U_{1}\cup U_{2} are not related by equality or disequality to variables in Vâˆ–(U1âˆªU2)ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘ˆ1subscriptğ‘ˆ2V\setminus(U_{1}\cup U_{2}). Thus, Zâ€‹(I)=(Î±+Î²)â€‹Zâ€‹(Iâ€²)ğ‘ğ¼ğ›¼ğ›½ğ‘superscriptğ¼â€²Z(I)=(\alpha+\beta)Z(I^{\prime}), where Iâ€²superscriptğ¼â€²I^{\prime} is the instance formed fromÂ Iğ¼I by removing this equivalence class. Suppose second that â„±â„±\mathcal{F} if pure affine. Then Zâ€‹(I)=âˆfâˆˆâ„±wfkfâ€‹Zâ€‹(Iâ€²)ğ‘ğ¼subscriptproductğ‘“â„±superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘“subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘“ğ‘superscriptğ¼â€²Z(I)=\prod_{f\in\mathcal{F}}w_{f}^{k_{f}}Z(I^{\prime}), where {0,wf}0subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘“\{0,w_{f}\} is the range ofÂ fğ‘“f, kfsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘“k_{f} is the number of constraints involving fğ‘“f inÂ Iğ¼I, and Iâ€²superscriptğ¼â€²I^{\prime} is the instance obtained fromÂ Iğ¼I by replacing every functionÂ fğ‘“f by its underlying relationÂ Rfsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘“R_{f} (viewed as a function with range {0,1}01\{0,1\}). Zâ€‹(Iâ€²)ğ‘superscriptğ¼â€²Z(I^{\prime}) is easy to evaluate, because this is just counting solutions to a linear system over GF(222), as Creignou and Hermann have observedÂ [6].

Finally, the #P-hardness in TheoremÂ 4 follows from LemmaÂ 5 below. âˆ

Lemma 5.

2.3 Pinning

For câˆˆ[q]ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘c\in[q], Î´csubscriptğ›¿ğ‘\delta_{c} denotes the unary function with Î´câ€‹(c)=1subscriptğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘1\delta_{c}(c)=1 and Î´câ€‹(d)=0subscriptğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘‘0\delta_{c}(d)=0 for dâ‰ cğ‘‘ğ‘d\neq c. 2.4 #P-hard problems

Lemma 14.

Lemma 16.

Suppose fâˆˆâ„±2ğ‘“subscriptâ„±2f\in\mathcal{F}_{2} is not of product type, and gâˆˆâ„±2ğ‘”subscriptâ„±2g\in\mathcal{F}_{2} is not pure affine. Then #CSPâ€‹({f,g,Î´0,Î´1})#CSPğ‘“ğ‘”subscriptğ›¿0subscriptğ›¿1\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,g,\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\}) is #P-hard.

If gğ‘”g does not have affine support we are done by LemmaÂ 11. So suppose that gğ‘”g has affine support. Since gğ‘”g is not pure affine, the range of gğ‘”g contains at least two non-zero values.

The high-level idea will be to use pinning and bisection to extract a non-trivial unary weight functionÂ UÎ»subscriptğ‘ˆğœ†U_{\lambda} fromÂ gğ‘”g.
